docs.lead_paragraph: Senate Democrats will press forward this week on legislation to overhaul the nation's financial system in a critical test of whether Washington can pass reform, Sewell Chan reports in The New York Times.

headline.main: With Financial Reform Bill, a Test for Congress

docs.lead_paragraph: Win or lose on health care, President Obama will face a vastly different political landscape after the fate of his plan is decided.

headline.main: As Health Vote Awaits, Future of a Presidency Waits, Too
headline.sub: Win or lose on health care, Obama will face a vastly different political landscape.;

docs.snippet: Win or lose on health care, President Obama will face a vastly different political landscape after the fate of his plan is decided.

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- Take a glance at the political map, and it makes perfect sense that President Obama will open the most critical week in his push for major health care legislation with a visit on Monday to the Walter F. Ehrnfelt Recreation and Senior Center, in Strongsville, Ohio. Just a quick 15-minute drive to the northeast, up Pearl Road, lies the Parma district office of Representative Dennis J. Kucinich, one of the 39 House Democrats who voted against the health care legislation in November.

headline.main: A National Measure, Inextricably Enmeshed With Local Interests
headline.kicker: PRESCRIPTIONS MAKING SENSE OF THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE

docs.abstract: Pres Obama, about to open critical week in his push for major health care legislation, plans to visit Walter F Ehrnfelt Recreation and Senior Center in Strongsville and 16th Congressional District office in Parma, Ohio; aim is to persuade Democratic Rep Dennis Kucinich and freshman Rep John Boccieri, who voted against health care legislation in November, to reconsider; photos (M)
